questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain for 3 hours. She has had no prenatal care. There is no leakage of amniotic fluid. Since arrival, she has had 5 contractions in 10 minutes, each lasting 70 to 90 seconds. Pelvic examination shows a closed cervix and a uterus consistent in size with a 38-week gestation. Ultrasound shows a single live intrauterine fetus in a breech presentation consistent with a gestational age of approximately 37 weeks. The amniotic fluid index is 26 cm (N = 10–20) and the fetal heart rate is 92/min. The placenta is not detached. She is scheduled for an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean delivery because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. The infant is delivered and APGAR score is noted to be 8 at 1 minute. The physician soon notices cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa, which does not resolve when the infant cries. The infant is foaming at the mouth and drooling. He also has an intractable cough. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An intractable cough, excessive oral secretions (e.g., drooling, foaming at the mouth), and cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa immediately after birth suggest a diagnosis of esophageal atresia. Infants with esophageal atresia are usually unable to swallow during the prenatal period, which results in polyhydramnios. Placement of an oroesophageal or nasoesophageal tube is used for continuous suction of secretions and prevents aspiration. Oral feeding should not be attempted. Patients with esophageal atresia should receive surgical treatment within the first 24 hours of birth.
Image Description:

X-ray (AP view with contrast): contrast agent filling a blind-ended esophageal pouch (green overlay) that ends at the level of the third thoracic vertebra. Inside the pouch, a nasogastric tube can be seen (dashed lines). There is abundant gas in the gastrointestinal tract, indicating patent tracheoesophageal fistula.

B) INCORRECT:

Choanal atresia manifests immediately after birth and causes cyanotic attacks. However, cyanosis improves when the baby cries, as this involves breathing through the mouth rather than through the obliterated nasal passage.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal stricture manifests as either a congenital or acquired disorder (e.g., after ingestion of batteries or caustic substances). Congenital esophageal stricture is usually not symptomatic at birth and only becomes apparent through dysphagia and regurgitation once the infant begins feeding with solid foods (i.e., around the weaning period). Additionally, esophageal stricture does not affect the airways and does not cause cyanotic attacks.

D) INCORRECT:

Achalasia is very rare in infants and occurs most commonly in middle-aged individuals. It causes dysphagia and regurgitation, which this infant does not exhibit. Moreover, because achalasia does not primarily affect the airways, it does not cause cyanosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypoplasia commonly manifests with cyanosis in newborns, but it does not cause coughing spells or drooling. Moreover, it is associated with oligohydramnios rather than polyhydramnios.

F) INCORRECT:

Several neurological and neuromuscular conditions, such as Down syndrome, cerebral palsy, and spinal muscular atrophy, are associated with a defective swallowing reflex. A defective swallowing reflex may cause some of the symptoms exhibited by this infant, such as drooling, coughing spells, and cyanotic attacks. However, both cerebral palsy and spinal muscular atrophy typically manifest with abnormal muscle tone, and Down syndrome causes typical facial skeletal abnormalities, neither of which is seen in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

After cesarean delivery, infants may still have amniotic fluid inside the lungs. This remnant is typically expelled during the first minutes after birth. Although it may cause excessive secretions, it resolves spontaneously. Cyanotic attacks and coughing spells do not normally occur after a C-section.
questions.hint: An amniotic fluid index indicating polyhydramnios (normal range is between 8–18) alongside cyanosis that does not improve with crying suggests a developmental anomaly.

questions.text: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of shortness of breath and noisy breathing for the past 2 weeks. She reports that the episodes are worse when he is agitated and better when he sleeps in supine position. During this period he has had frequent regurgitation of his feeds. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. The neonatal period was complicated by transient tachypnea. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 94/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows subcostal retractions. Stridor and diffuse wheezing are heard in the thorax. Anteroposterior and lateral x-rays of the chest show anterior tracheal bowing and narrowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical division of a vascular ring

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Racemic epinephrine is used to treat upper airway obstruction caused by severe croup, which is a common cause of respiratory symptoms in young children (although uncommon in children < 3 months of age). Croup manifests with hoarseness and a barking cough; fever and rhinorrhea may also be seen. This patient has stridor but no fever or rhinorrhea. Moreover, in croup, x-ray shows a steeple sign, not tracheal bowing.
Image Description:

X-ray neck of a young child (AP view)

The upper tracheal air column, which normally appears with a square-shouldered configuration, has assumed a conical shape (green overlay) reminiscent of a church steeple (steeple sign; cf. illustration).

The steeple sign indicates subglottic airway narrowing and is most commonly seen in croup. However, it may also appear in other conditions (e.g., bacterial tracheitis, tumors). An accompanying lateral radiograph might additionally show inspiratory overdistention of the hypopharynx.

B) INCORRECT:

Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) causes respiratory distress, drooling, choking, and an inability to feed in newborns; it is unlikely to present in a 5-week-old infant. In addition, the majority of patients with TEF have a history of polyhydramnios due to the inability of the fetus to swallow amniotic fluid. Furthermore, TEF does not explain this patient's stridor or x-ray findings.
Image Description:

Gross type A: esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type B: esophageal atresia with an upper tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type C: esophageal atresia with a lower tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type D: esophageal atresia with upper and lower tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type E: tracheoesophageal fistula without atresia

C) INCORRECT:

Nebulized albuterol is used to treat acute asthma, which typically manifests with sudden shortness of breath, wheezing, and a dry cough that usually worsens at night. This patient presents with shortness of breath and wheezing, but his symptoms improve at night. In addition, chest x-ray findings in acute asthma exacerbation are expected to show hyperinflation of the lungs, not tracheal changes.

D) CORRECT:

A vascular ring is a rare cause of respiratory symptoms in infants that is treated with surgical division. Vascular rings typically manifest with shortness of breath, wheezing, stridor due to tracheal compression, as well as difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and/or unintended weight loss resulting from esophageal compression. The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of tracheal and esophageal compression by the vascular ring. X-ray typically shows tracheal bowing and narrowing, indicating tracheal compression.
Image Description:

Ventral view of mediastinal structures

There is constriction of the trachea and esophagus as a result of the additional aortic arch (vascular ring anomaly).

E) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is indicated for bacterial airway infection (e.g., epiglottitis), which can manifest with respiratory distress and inspiratory stridor. However, it usually also manifests in older children with sore throat, dysphagia, drooling, and acute onset of high fever, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, x-ray of the epiglottitis often shows a characteristic thumbprint sign (enlarged epiglottis), not the tracheal changes seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view)

The epiglottis is swollen and rounded in appearance (thumb sign; highlighted by green overlay and black arrow) as a result of inflammation and edema. The normal air space between the tongue base and epiglottis has been almost entirely obliterated and is seen only as a shallow V-shaped space (vallecula sign; highlighted by red line).

The thumb and vallecula signs are useful in the radiographic evaluation of epiglottitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Supraglottoplasty is performed in severe cases of laryngomalacia. This condition typically manifests with low-pitched inspiratory stridor that worsens in the supine position and during sleeping or feeding. Other symptoms of laryngomalacia include reflux, swallowing dysfunction, and, in severe cases, failure to thrive. This patient presents with stridor that improves in the supine position and during sleeping. In addition, chest x-ray findings suggest involvement of the trachea rather than the larynx.
questions.hint: This patient's underlying condition is a rare but important cause of respiratory symptoms in infants. The presence of stridor (suggesting upper airway obstruction) and regurgitation of feeds (due to esophageal compression) are important clues.

questions.text: Sixteen hours after delivery, a newborn develops respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation with a birth weight of 3200 g (7 lb 1 oz). Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Physical examination shows tachypnea and bluish discoloration of the extremities. Auscultation of the chest shows diffuse crackles in the lung fields and a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Abdominal x-ray shows absence of bowel gas. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this newborn's condition?

choices.text: Deletion in the long arm of chromosome 7
Deletion in the long arm of chromosome 22

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane is responsible for congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), which can cause features of respiratory distress shortly after birth. However, in patients with CDH, examination would show diminished or absent breath sounds in the one lung field (typically the left) and a chest x-ray would reveal bowel loops in the lung field with diminished breath sounds. These features are not reported in this patient.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray, PA view, in a newborn.

Mediastinal shift to the right (solid line: mediastinal border in this patient; dashed line: approximate physiologic position), bowel loops within the left thoracic cavity (green marking), and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax.

B) INCORRECT:

A microdeletion in the long arm of chromosome 7 is responsible for Williams syndrome, which can manifest with a systolic murmur due to supravalvular aortic stenosis and features of respiratory distress due to heart failure. However, the murmur of aortic stenosis would be best heard at the right upper sternal border (aortic area), and heart failure typically occurs during early childhood, not during the neonatal period. Moreover, features of esophageal atresia such as absence of bowel gas would not be expected and elfin facies, which is characteristic of Williams syndrome, has not been reported in this patient.
Image Description:

Photograph of a child with a broad forehead, midfacial hypoplasia, a short nose (with a flat nasal bridge), an everted lower lip, full cheeks and lips and low-set ears.

This appearance is often described as “elfin” facies and commonly seen in Williams syndrome, although definitive diagnosis would require genetic testing.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased phosphatidylcholine production is common in premature infants (< 36 weeks) and causes neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). However, this infant was born at 38 weeks, at which point her lungs have likely reached a sufficient degree of maturation. Additionally, maternal polyhydramnios, a harsh holosystolic murmur at the tricuspid area, and a lack of bowel gas on imaging are not characteristic features of NRDS. Instead, NRDS is associated with a continuous murmur best heard in the interscapular region (due to a patent ductus arteriosus) and/or features of necrotizing enterocolitis on abdominal x-ray (e.g., pneumatosis intestinalis, free air in the abdomen).

D) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms of respiratory distress and auscultatory findings are most likely caused by an aspiration, which can occur due to a tracheoesophageal fistula. Combined with esophageal atresia and a ventricular septal defect, these malformations suggest a VACTERL association, which is caused by defective mesodermal development. Other VACTERL features include vertebral defects, anal atresia, renal defects, and limb defects.
Image Description:

Gross type A: esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type B: esophageal atresia with an upper tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type C: esophageal atresia with a lower tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type D: esophageal atresia with upper and lower tracheoesophageal fistula

Gross type E: tracheoesophageal fistula without atresia

E) INCORRECT:

The absence of functional dynein is responsible for Kartagener syndrome, which can cause respiratory distress due to LRTI as a result of impaired mucociliary clearance. However, the onset of respiratory distress in the immediate postnatal period, the presence of a harsh systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area), and features of esophageal atresia such as absence of bowel gas are not consistent with Kartagener syndrome. Instead, examination would show heart sounds over the right precordium as a result of dextrocardia (situs inversus).

F) INCORRECT:

DiGeorge syndrome can cause a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border due to a ventricular septal defect (associated with conotruncal anomalies) as well as respiratory distress and cyanosis. However, patients with DiGeorge often have distinctive facial features (e.g., a cleft lip or palate, broad nasal bridge, ocular hypertelorism, dysplastic ears, micrognathia). Moreover, the absence of bowel gas on imaging is not consistent with DiGeorge syndrome.
Image Description:

Broad nasal bridge and nasal tip, ocular hypertelorism, dysplastic and low-set ears as well as micrognathia.
questions.hint: This patient's respiratory distress shortly after birth, cyanosis, and crackles on lung auscultation are concerning for an aspiration phenomenon. The harsh holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border is consistent with a ventricular septal defect. Polyhydramnios during pregnancy and lack of bowel gas on imaging are suggestive of a diagnosis of esophageal atresia.

questions.text: One hour after delivery, a 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) male newborn starts to cough and choke while being breastfed. He was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation because of premature rupture of membranes. Apgar scores were 8 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His parents refused prenatal screening. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, respirations are 51/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Examination shows cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa. Crackles are heard throughout both lung bases. There is a harsh 3/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border. Insertion of a nasogastric tube is attempted but the tube cannot be passed beyond 6 cm from the gums. An x-ray with contrast shows a blind-ended esophageal pouch; there is abundant gas in the stomach. Screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Esophageal atresia with TEF is caused by a defect in mesodermal differentiation. About 50% of esophageal atresia cases are associated with other mesodermal defects, known as the VACTERL association: Vertebral anomaly, Anal atresia, Cardiac anomaly, Tracheoesophageal fistula, Esophageal atresia, Renal anomaly (including agenesis), and Limb malformation. Newborns with esophageal atresia should, therefore, undergo screening for other VACTERL anomalies. Screening typically includes echocardiography and renal ultrasonography.

Esophageal atresia with TEF to the distal esophageal segment is the most common type of esophageal atresia, accounting for > 75% of cases. A fetus with esophageal atresia is unable to swallow amniotic fluid, resulting in polyhydramnios, which can lead to premature rupture of membranes and premature labor, as seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray (AP view with contrast): contrast agent filling a blind-ended esophageal pouch (green overlay) that ends at the level of the third thoracic vertebra. Inside the pouch, a nasogastric tube can be seen (dashed lines). There is abundant gas in the gastrointestinal tract, indicating patent tracheoesophageal fistula.

B) INCORRECT:

Thymic aplasia may be seen in neonates with DiGeorge syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies, which this patient most likely has. However, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as an anomalous face (micrognathia, dysplastic ears, prominent nasal bridge) and a cleft palate. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include thymic aplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerebellar hypoplasia can be seen in children with PHACE syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies, which this patient most likely has. However, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of PHACE syndrome, such as infantile hemangiomas and eye anomalies. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include cerebellar hypoplasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Iris coloboma may be seen in neonates with CHARGE syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies and bilateral choanal atresia, which can manifest immediately after birth with cyanosis associated with feeding, similar to what is seen in this newborn. However, choanal atresia does not typically manifest with coughing and choking spells. Moreover, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of CHARGE syndrome, such as genital and ear abnormalities. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include iris coloboma.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal atresia, which this newborn has, may be associated with gastrointestinal abnormalities, such as anal atresia and intestinal malrotation. Biliary atresia, however, is not a common association. Furthermore, biliary atresia typically manifests at birth with jaundice, which is not seen in this newborn.
questions.hint: Coughing and choking spells when feeding, in conjunction with cyanosis, crackles on lung auscultation, and the inability to pass a feeding tube, suggest esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). This diagnosis is confirmed by the x-ray findings. The harsh systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation suggests a cardiac structural anomaly.

questions.text:
A female neonate is evaluated in the newborn nursery after experiencing multiple episodes of gagging with mild cyanosis and nonbilious emesis. She was born 6 hours ago at 36 weeks' gestation after a pregnancy complicated by polyhydramnios and preterm labor; the delivery was uncomplicated. She has attempted to breastfeed but has had excessive oral secretions and clear emesis during and after the attempts.
She has a temperature of 37.0°C, a respiratory rate of 70 breaths per minute, and a heart rate of 140 beats per minute. She has pre- and postductal oxygen saturations of 97% while breathing ambient air, with intermittent cyanotic spells that resolve with oral suctioning. She has watery, profuse oral secretions and coarse upper-airway sounds. Her cardiovascular examination is unremarkable. Her abdomen is nondistended and soft.
An orogastric tube is placed to decompress the stomach, and a radiograph of the chest and abdomen is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely cause of this infant’s feeding intolerance?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The classic radiographic finding associated with duodenal atresia is the “double bubble” of an air-filled stomach and a very dilated proximal duodenum, with paucity of air distal to the atretic portion of the duodenum.

B) INCORRECT:

A TEF without esophageal atresia (referred to as an H-type fistula) would demonstrate air in the stomach or intestinal lumen on radiograph. Furthermore, H-type fistulas do not always manifest symptomatically in the newborn period, given that there is no gastrointestinal obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Most patients with esophageal atresia have a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), with the most common configuration being a proximal esophageal pouch with a distal TEF. If a TEF is present, acidic gastric juices may reflux through the fistula, irritating the airways and exacerbating any coexisting respiratory distress related to prematurity or intolerance of excessive oral secretions. A TEF to the distal part of the discontinuous esophagus will result in tracking of inhaled air from the trachea into the stomach and intestines. Therefore, the presence of air in the intestinal lumen of a patient with esophageal atresia is diagnostic for TEF.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view)

The unsuccessful placement of a nasogastric tube (green overlay) resulted in curling of the tube in the region of the proximal esophagus, although air is seen in the stomach (S) and small bowel.

The above findings suggest esophageal atresia with a proximal stump and a distal tracheo-esophageal fistula (Type C esophageal atresia).

D) CORRECT:

Esophageal atresia is a structural gastrointestinal obstruction that manifests with copious oral secretions, interferes with feeding immediately after birth, and can lead to respiratory distress. Because esophageal atresia can cause reduced fetal swallowing, polyhydramnios is commonly seen in fetuses with this anomaly. Affected neonates will present with drooling, immediate intolerance of even small feeding volumes and emesis during feedings (both of which can lead to dehydration), episodes of choking, and potential aspiration.

Postnatal diagnosis of esophageal atresia is made by inserting a radiopaque orogastric tube and evaluating its depth on a plain-film radiograph. If esophageal atresia is present, the tube will not pass to the expected depth and will be visualized in the proximal esophageal pouch (as in this case).

Most patients with esophageal atresia have a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), with the most common configuration being a proximal esophageal pouch with a distal TEF. If a TEF is present, acidic gastric juices may reflux through the fistula, irritating the airways and exacerbating any coexisting respiratory distress related to prematurity or intolerance of excessive oral secretions.

A TEF to the distal part of the discontinuous esophagus will result in tracking of inhaled air from the trachea into the stomach and intestines. Therefore, the presence of air in the intestinal lumen of a patient with esophageal atresia is diagnostic for TEF.

This patient's radiograph shows no air in the stomach or the intestinal lumen and is therefore consistent with esophageal atresia without TEF.

Esophageal atresia requires surgical repair. However, immediate management involves administration of intravenous dextrose-containing fluids (to prevent dehydration and hypoglycemia) and provision of parenteral nutrition (to optimize protein balance for wound healing after operative repair). If the distance between the discontinuous parts of the esophagus is too great for primary repair, the infant may require a gastrostomy tube to receive enteral feeds while awaiting definitive repair.

If the proximal esophageal pouch is collecting oral secretions and impairing respiratory function, a Replogle suction catheter (set to low-to-intermittent wall suction) can be placed in the pouch.

Key learning point: An orogastric tube that will not pass to the expected depth in a neonate is diagnostic for esophageal atresia.

E) INCORRECT:

Intestinal malrotation with volvulus can initially manifest in a benign fashion, but as the intestine becomes hypoxic and necrotic, it causes a profound clinical illness characterized by a distended abdomen and lactic acidosis. On a plain-film radiograph, the stomach will appear very dilated, with a paucity of air distal to the volvulus.

questions.text:
A newborn girl is born full-term to a mother with poor prenatal care. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios with antenatal ultrasound evidence of absent left kidney. The delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at one and five minutes, respectively. Initial examination is notable for absent right thumb.
When the baby attempts to nurse, she does not latch well and is noted to have copious oral secretions.
At 2 hours of life, she develops respiratory distress and is transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit for further management.
A complete blood count, blood cultures, and venous blood gas are sent; intravenous access is obtained; and a nasogastric tube is placed to initiate feeding.
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure):
Which one of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Tracheoesophageal fistula without esophageal atresia (type E)
Esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistula (type A)
Esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula (type C)
Esophageal atresia with both proximal and distal tracheoesophageal fistulae (type D)
Esophageal atresia with proximal tracheoesophageal fistula (type B)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Type E (TE fistula without esophageal atresia) typically manifests with dysphagia and respiratory distress associated with feeding, as well as recurrent lower respiratory tract infections related to chronic aspiration. Signs of type E fistulae may be subtle or even missed during infancy, whereas this patient’s signs were evident during the first hours of life. Moreover, the coiling of this patient’s nasogastric tube on radiography represents esophageal atresia, thereby excluding the possibility of a type E fistula.

B) INCORRECT:

In type A (esophageal atresia without TE fistula), the stomach is not contiguous with the esophagus or the trachea, so it appears gasless on imaging. In contrast, this patient’s chest radiograph showed air in the stomach.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s history and clinical findings are consistent with esophageal atresia and a distal tracheoesophageal (TE) fistula. Clues to the atresia include the patient’s copious oral secretions, the coiled nasogastric tube seen in the proximal esophagus on chest radiography, and the history of intrauterine polyhydramnios, which is common in patients with esophageal atresia. The presence of gastric air on imaging is consistent with a distal (or type C) TE fistula.

Esophageal atresia with and without TE fistula is one of the most common congenital anomalies of the gastrointestinal tract, occurring in 2.7 to 3.4 per 10,000 live births. About half of all patients with a TE fistula have other congenital anomalies as well. In this particular case, the patient has both an absent left kidney and absent right thumb, consistent with the VACTERL association.

VACTERL association, a rare condition affecting 1 in 40,000 to 1 in 10,000 live births, is typically defined by the presence of at least three of the following congenital anomalies: v ertebral defects, a nal atresia, c ardiac defects, TE fistula, r enal anomalies, and l imb anomalies. TE fistula is seen in approximately 50% to 80% of cases.

Esophageal atresia and TE fistulae are classified into types A through E, with type C being the most common by far in both VACTERL- and non-VACTERL-associated cases. See “Overview of types of esophageal atresia” table.

Key learning point: The most common type of tracheoesophageal fistula in patients with VACTERL association is esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula (type C).

D) INCORRECT:

Type D (esophageal atresia with both proximal and distal TE fistulae) is rare, accounting for only 1% to 3% of all TE fistulae, and is therefore unlikely in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

In type B (esophageal atresia with proximal TE fistula), the stomach is not contiguous with the esophagus or the trachea, so it appears gasless on imaging. In contrast, this patient’s chest radiograph showed air in the stomach.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy, born at term and otherwise healthy, presents for his well-child check. His parents note that, since birth, they have occasionally heard wheezing sounds when he breathes, although they have not noticed him having any difficulty breathing and were never too concerned. The wheezing sounds tend to occur when he tucks his chin into his chest and not when he is lying flat in his crib. He does not have any difficulty feeding, is not coughing or gagging during his feeds, and does not sweat or tire when eating.
On examination, he is active and alert. He has an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air, a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. He is growing well and is at the 80th percentile for weight and 85th percentile for height. He has no cardiac murmur.
During the examination, his mother is holding him on her chest, and you note some mild wheezing at rest, potentiated when his neck is held in the flexed position. When you extend his neck and continue to auscultate, both lungs are clear.
Which one of the following next steps would most likely confirm the diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Administration of a proton pump inhibitor

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Vascular rings and slings are rare but important diagnoses to consider in an infant with wheezing. These conditions occur when a vascular anomaly causes compression of a large airway such as the trachea. Vascular rings completely encircle the trachea and esophagus, leading to significant symptoms, whereas vascular slings tend to cause less severe symptoms. In both conditions, flexion of the neck further narrows the airway, making the wheeze more audible, whereas extension tends to minimize compression of the airway, alleviating or obscuring the physical finding of wheeze. This patient’s symptoms are mild without any signs of dysphagia noted, making the presentation more consistent with a sling than a ring. Other abnormalities that can cause compression or narrowing of the trachea, including tracheomalacia, may yield similar findings and should also be considered. Vascular rings and slings often require multiple imaging studies for accurate diagnosis; CT angiography is the most sensitive.

Key learning point: An otherwise healthy infant who presents with wheezing that worsens with neck flexion and that is relieved by neck extension should be evaluated for a vascular ring or sling.

B) INCORRECT:

Clinicians evaluating patients with wheeze should remember that not all wheezing is related to asthma. Given this patient’s age, the fact that his symptoms have been present since birth, and the intermittent audible wheeze without a clear trigger, asthma is an unlikely diagnosis. Therefore, a bronchodilator would not be appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Foreign-body aspiration typically manifests with acute-onset wheezing, often immediately preceded by a history of choking or coughing, and is typically seen in older children who are more mobile than a 6-month-old infant would be. This patient has no reported history of coughing or choking, and his wheeze has been present since birth. Furthermore, his wheeze varies with neck flexion and extension, a phenomenon not seen with foreign-body aspiration. Bronchoscopy is therefore not warranted in this case. In children with vascular anomalies, bronchoscopy can determine the level of airway obstruction but will not define the exact etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Although an infant with cystic fibrosis (CF) could present with wheezing related to ciliary dysfunction and poor mucus clearance, positional changes would not alleviate the wheezing, as they do in this patient. In addition, intermittent wheezing would be unlikely to be the first presenting symptom of CF, and other findings such as failure to thrive would be more common. Therefore, a sweat test would not be indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux is a common cause of wheezing in young infants, but the wheezing is typically associated with feeding and coughing, as well as vomiting. In addition, gastroesophageal reflux is usually exacerbated when the baby is supine, because lying on the back flattens the gastroesophageal junction and allows for more reflux. This patient’s presentation is not consistent with reflux, and thus a proton pump inhibitor is not indicated.
